etymologies: late 16th century (in subtend (sense 1)): from Latin subtendere, from sub- ‘under’ + tendere ‘stretch’. subtend (sense 2) dates from the late 19th century

definitions: (of a line, arc, or figure) form (an angle) at a particular point when straight lines from its extremities are joined at that point

examples.text: the angle subtended by a string of length r at the center of the sphere

shortDefinitions: (of line, arc, or figure) form angle at particular point when straight lines from its extremities are joined at that point

definitions: (of an angle or chord) have bounding lines or points that meet or coincide with those of (a line or arc).
shortDefinitions: (of angle or chord) have bounding lines or points that meet or coincide with those of

definitions: (of a bract) extend under (a flower) so as to support or enfold it

examples.text: the main beauty is provided by the bracts which subtend the flowers

shortDefinitions: (of bract) extend under flower so as to support or enfold it
